185929254.review:
个人评分8/10

（目前打完本体和女巫追猎）

如果抛开剧情不谈的话，这款15年前的游戏无疑已经完全过时，且存在诸多不利于游玩的场外因素：
-steam版几乎无法直接玩，必须打内存补丁；且游戏内也存在不少大大小小的bug；
-在玩过龙腾世纪3以后再玩本作，我仍然对rtwp式战斗总体上持负面态度；不过值得一提的是鼠标操作有一点玩rts的感觉，反而比手柄操作要舒服不少，比如让整个小队移动到某处、集火攻击，鼠标可以直接框选，手柄大概必须分别设定每个角色的行为吧……
-画面老旧，美术设计虽自成风格但缺陷严重，比如盔甲无限换皮；
-无官方中文，民间汉化补丁虽有高光发挥但也大多存在肉眼可见的错译，结合本作的巨大文本量和丰富剧情，如果不打双语mod纯看汉化补丁的字幕大概率会影响正常游玩；
-通马桶支线，龙腾世纪3的逆天马桶支线并非无本之木；虽然本作不至于那么离谱但我对支线的观感还是偏负面；
-游戏整体架构过时，战斗充斥着堆怪，战斗流程几乎称得上重复、冗长（不得不承认rtwp式战斗确实适合堆怪，如果直接改回合制的话估计流程会更加拖沓）。

但是说回剧情，对于喜欢黑暗奇幻、队友剧情与人物塑造、角色扮演代入感、拯救世界的正道龙傲天剧情、选择取向塑造世界[spoiler]（包括大量两难抉择）[/spoiler]的玩家来说，本作带来的还是顶级的剧情体验；并且n网也有不少mod可以对以上缺点进行一定程度的改善。

10/10
This has been my favorite game since I first played it in 2009.
A friend told me that it was like KotOR.
I never ran to the store faster to buy a game in my life.

I fell in love with the story & the characters.
I didn't initially love every character, but they all grew on me over time.

I liked the gameplay in KotOR & of course this was leagues better.
Mods make the combat (along w/ everything else) even better & I feel like it's aged well.
I never skip The Fade & I liked the Deep Roads.

The only issues really being instability that the memory leak patch mostly fixes.
The game needs to be closed & restarted every so often.
And an audio quality issue that many people don't seem to notice.
Character dialogue is too "sharp" at times & is painful to the point of being unplayable for me.
No other game does this, & I didn't have this issue on Xbox 360.
After 10 years, I finally found a solution w/ an equalizer:
31Hz/63Hz/125Hz/250Hz/500Hz/1kHz/2kHz/4kHz at +12dB 
8kHz/16kHz at -12dB
The 8kHz is the culprit.

So many playthroughs I lost count... (12+)
I played this game every year until 2015~ when the audio (dialogue) started to cause me physical pain.

185812327.review:
Hands down one of the best RPGs ever made.
Origin has a lot of meaningful choices that give you the impression that you are crafting your own story  (with a good "illusion" of a branching path: in the end, you will always fight the Archdemon), the characters are interesting and will always remain true to their motivations and nature within the context of their arcs, the quest design is really good (most of the quests are complex and "tiring" in a good way), and the art style is fantastic.
Top-tier voice acting (Loghain, in particular, comes to mind).

I consider The Landsmeet one of the highest notes in gaming.

Some people refer at the combat as too old-style, in truth it has a lot of depth and feels fresh with each new playthrough.

Speaking of combat, however, and only while playing the post-game DLC "The Golems of Amgarrak" some of the problems that unfortunately will plague the sequel (Dragon Age II) were already noticeable here when it comes to gameplay, such as enemy spawns and sudden difficulty spikes. 

It's also worth mentioning that there are some technical issues while playing on modern hardware. Either you install the 4 GB update (check the Steam forum for all the info), which should fix most of the problems, or the game will crash here and there.

185665406.review:
A Classic RPG That Hasn’t Aged Gracefully

Dragon Age: Origins - Ultimate Edition is often hailed as a masterpiece of RPG storytelling, but playing it today reveals a game that feels clunky, outdated, and riddled with frustrations. While its ambition and depth are commendable, the experience is marred by dated mechanics, uneven pacing, and technical issues that detract from its appeal.

The game’s strongest aspect is its world-building. Ferelden is a rich, detailed setting filled with political intrigue, complex factions, and deep lore. However, the story, while epic in scope, is fairly generic and relies heavily on well-worn fantasy tropes. The "chosen hero saves the world from an ancient evil" plotline feels predictable, and the game's attempts at moral ambiguity often boil down to black-and-white decisions with obvious consequences.

The companions, a hallmark of the BioWare formula, are hit or miss. While characters like Morrigan and Alistair are memorable and well-written, others feel underdeveloped or lack meaningful arcs. Companion relationships are heavily tied to gift-giving mechanics, which feel more like a grind than genuine character development.

Gameplay is where Dragon Age: Origins shows its age the most. The combat system, while strategic, feels slow and repetitive. The AI is frustrating to manage, and the tactics system, while robust, requires constant micromanagement to prevent your party from making boneheaded decisions. Battles quickly devolve into spamming abilities and hoping your healer doesn’t get overwhelmed, which becomes tedious over time.

The visuals are another glaring issue. Even for a game from 2009, the graphics feel dated, with stiff animations, awkward facial expressions, and bland textures. The Ultimate Edition includes all the DLC, but this only adds more uneven content to an already bloated experience. Some DLCs, like Awakening, are worthwhile, but others feel like filler that doesn’t justify their inclusion.

The pacing of the game is also a problem. The main story is lengthy, but much of that time is padded with repetitive side quests, endless backtracking, and large, empty areas that feel like a chore to navigate. Dungeons, in particular, are overly long and lack variety, making exploration feel more like a slog than an adventure.

Technically, the game has its fair share of issues. On modern systems, Dragon Age: Origins can be prone to crashes, performance problems, and compatibility issues. The controls and UI are clunky, especially for PC players, and feel poorly optimized for mouse and keyboard.

While Dragon Age: Origins was groundbreaking in its time, the Ultimate Edition doesn’t do enough to address the game’s shortcomings or bring it up to modern standards. It’s a game that may still appeal to nostalgic fans or those willing to overlook its flaws, but for new players, it’s a tough sell in a world where more polished and engaging RPGs exist.

185504074.review:
В дни былой славы Bioware умели и могли так, что единственным эпитетом, полностью отражающим весь размах, было слово «ЭПИЧНО». Именно так, большими буквами. И эта эпичная история началась с релизом Baldur’s Gate, которая перевернула представление о компьютерных ролевых играх в своё время.

Потом были Baldur’s Gate 2, Neverwinter Nights, и с каждым релизом скилл канадской студии только рос. С выходом Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic сформировался именно тот образ «RPG от Bioware», который затем закрепился в умах игроков. Это было увлекательное приключение с масштабной историей, в которой можно было выбирать, как будут развиваться дальнейшие события, и живыми персонажами, реагирующими на действия протагониста и иногда выясняющими друг с другом отношения. А в 2007 разработчики выпустили Mass Effect, которая стала важной вехой в их подходе к геймдизайну ролевых игр — краеугольными камнями стали экшн и кинематографичность. Потом это ещё сильно отразится на их последующих играх, но к 2009 году концепция типичной ролевой игры Bioware образца SW KOTOR сохранилась.

Так вот, ЭПИЧНЫЙ Dargon Age: Origins. Духовный наследник серии Baldur’s Gate — так назвал DAO один из основателей Bioware, Рэй Музика. Игра действительно воплотила в себе все особенности BG (фэнтезийный сеттинг, фокус на сюжете и персонажах, боевая механика с тактической паузой), при этом сохранив самобытность за счёт интересного проработанного лора и атмосферы тёмного фентези. 

Главная особенность DAO — вариативность. Совершенно разные прологи при выборе определённой расы или класса — это, наверное, первое, что бросается в глаза. Игрок также решает, в каком порядке проходить сюжетные арки; от его действий зависит не только судьба ключевых персонажей, но и лояльность спутников. Делая конкретный выбор по ходу выполнения квестов или отыгрывая роль, игрок может выгнать спутника из партии или даже убить его. Спутники в Dragon Age это вообще отдельная история, говорить о них можно долго и много.

[quote]Лелиана: Я слышала, ты дочь Флемет, ведьмы из дебрей Коркари.
Морриган: А я слышала, что ты мыла ноги зимой и простудила мозги, но мы ведь все знаем, что это неправда. Но иногда слухи не врут, и в этом они правы.[/quote]

По части геймплея в плане прогрессии персонажа тоже имеется вариативность: игра за воина, разбойника и мага при определённой прокачке — это совершенно разный опыт. Если, например, играть за волшебника и выбрать специализацию Боевой маг, геймплей максимально преобразится: из дистанционного хлюпика маг превратится в танка в тяжелой броне с мечом и щитом. В системе прогрессии разных классов есть, конечно, сомнительные навыки, но тут, скорее, зависит от билда и предпочтений в стиле ведения боя.

Система лута и экипировка типичная для представителя жанра: с большим количеством оружия, брони и аксессуаров. Некоторые вещи улучшаются рунами.

Крафт довольно неплохо вписан в игровой процесс и максимально полезен на высоких уровнях сложности. Разделён на три категории: зелья, яды и ловушки. Заниматься крафтом расходников интересно — для каждой категории качается свой навык, нужны рецепты и ингредиенты. Что-то можно найти, что-то — купить. 

К слову, про купить. Экономика реализована хорошо — деньги не сыпятся как из рога изобилия, накапливаются с трудом, тратить всегда есть на что. На первых порах помогает воровство. Взлом тоже обязателен к прокачке, потому что в запертых сундуках можно найти уникальные вещи.

В общем, если вы уже играли в Baldur’s Gate или другие классические crpg, то в Dragon Age освоитесь моментально. Настоятельно рекомендую. Лично для меня DAO это прям представитель Золотого фонда cRPG, мастхэв и "12 из 10".

185468461.review:
[h1]Steam Review für Dragon Age: Origins [/h1]

[b]Dragon Age: Origins[/b] ist ein Meisterwerk, bei dem Game of Thrones und Die Sims in einer epischen Midlife-Crisis ein Kind bekommen haben. Es hat alles, was man sich wünscht: tragische Entscheidungen, moralische Grauzonen und mehr Blutfontänen als eine Splatterparty auf einem Schlachthof.

Du willst ein Held sein, der die Welt rettet? Viel Glück, denn die Welt erwartet gleichzeitig, dass du Botengänge machst, Ratten im Keller erschlägst und dich mit Leuten streitest, die beleidigt sind, weil du das falsche Geschenk ausgewählt hast. („Was? Du hast mir eine Blume gegeben? Ich wollte eine verdammte Steinplatte!“).

[h2]Die Begleiter sind fantastisch:[/h2]

    -Ein arroganter, aber sexy Elf, der bei jedem Gespräch klingt, als ob er im Shakespeare-Theater aufgewachsen ist.
    -Eine Hexe, die dich bei jedem Dialog subtil darauf hinweist, dass sie klüger ist als du (Spoiler: Sie hat recht).
    -Ein Zwerg, dessen Hauptcharakterzug „Alkohol“ ist.

Und dann ist da noch Alistair. Er hat mehr Daddy-Issues als ganz Ferelden zusammen und ist das lebende Meme des Satzes: [i]„Ich mache das nicht, aber wehe, du machst es falsch.“	[/i]

[h2]Der Kampf?[/h2]

Ein Mix aus Strategie und Chaos. Entweder du paust jeden Angriff, weil dein Magier sonst denkt, es wäre schlau, in die feindliche Armee zu rennen, oder du klickst hektisch, bis irgendwas stirbt. Im schlimmsten Fall bist du das.

Aber keine Sorge, wenn du stirbst, kannst du wenigstens in der Charaktererstellung fünf Stunden verbringen, um deinen Warden so zu designen, dass er entweder aussieht wie ein Model oder wie ein Kartoffelsack mit Augen.

[h2]Fazit:[/h2]
Ein fantastisches Rollenspiel mit packender Story, herrlich nervigen Begleitern und genug Dialogoptionen, um dich wie ein manipulativer Psychologe zu fühlen. Außerdem: mehr Blut als nötig, mehr Drama als ein Teenager-Film und mehr verlorene Stunden als ich zugeben möchte.

10/10, würde wieder Alistair nerven.

185465810.review:
Hey, if you're looking for an epic RPG that'll totally suck you in, Dragon Age: Origins is the real deal. BioWare absolutely nailed it with this game. What makes it so awesome is how you can actually shape your character's entire backstory - I mean, each origin story feels totally unique.

The storytelling is just mind-blowing. Your choices actually matter here, which isn't something you can say about most games. The companions are incredible - each one feels like a real person with their own complicated history. Seriously, I got so invested in characters like Alistair and Morrigan that I felt like they were my actual friends.

The combat system is super tactical - you'll need to pause and think about your strategy, which I love. No mindless button mashing here. And Ferelden? The world-building is just *chef's kiss*. The graphics might be a bit dated now, but the atmosphere is still incredible.

If you're into RPGs and want a game that'll give you a solid 50 hours of pure immersion, Dragon Age: Origins is absolutely worth your time. Trust me, you won't regret picking this up.

185464383.review:
Dragon Age: Origins, along with the Awakening expansion and all the story DLCs, has become a great introduction to the entire DA series. Having had the opportunity to play this game in the year of its release - 2009, I immediately knew that it would be an interesting world that would draw me in. I spent a lot of hours playing the game - not only to unlock all the achievements, but also to experience all the elements of the game. I played over 500 hours on Origin and another 170 hours on Steam. Although it is possible to complete the game with the best possible result by choosing the right options, I tried every combination, often deciding on actions that I did not necessarily like.

The world of Dragon Age has everything a fantasy fan needs - humans, elves, dwarves and the mysterious gray giants - the Qunari. Additionally, you can play as a mage, a warrior and a rogue, wandering the city alleys, and wilderness. The story revolves around our hero, one of the last Gray Wardens of Ferelden, and the mysterious Blight - a terrible event that causes filthy creatures called darkspawns to set out from the underground (Deep Roads) to conquer the surface world. They are encouraged to do so by a powerful archdemon - a corrupted dragon, ready to raze the entire world to the ground. In addition to the intrigue of a mysterious Blight, we also deal with religious conflicts, slavery and racism occurring in the fantasy world. Humans hate elves. Dwarves hate elves. Elves are pushed to the margins of society. However, the game allows you to play as a representative of any race, providing an immersive jump into the story.

Unfortunately, my favorite race, dwarves, cannot be mages, which is explained in the game's plot.

In addition to the base story campaign, DAO also offers a large story expansion and DLC adding additional, smaller campaigns. During the game, you can visit ancient ruins, wild woods and forests, go deep underground and wander through the streets of bustling cities. You will face many different opponents - including the titular, legendary dragons.

Dragon Age: Origins is a single-player game. However, it allows you to join several companions to support you during your travels. Among them there are four who would like to become more than just companions, coleagues or good friends - Alistair, Leliana, Morrigan and Zevran, because we are talking about them, can become romantic partners of your Gray Warden. Interactions with companions, their involvement in the world around them, the ability to give them gifts and the overall of their character add charm to the gameplay.
If someone is a fan of cRPG games, they will definitely find many hours of great, addictive and interesting gameplay here.

Pros:
- immersive, dark fantasy world
- bunch of really neatly written companions
- romances for everyone
- great soundtrack, adding to the dark vibe of the game
- rich lore
- hours and hours of content
- your choices matter(!)

Cons:
- clunky mechanics and combat gameplay
- old graphics
- outdated, socially incorrect content in some places (game, studio behind it and the franchise evolved over the years)

Final rating: 9.7/10

185020608.review:
Ho acquistato l'intera trilogia in concomitanza con l'uscita del controverso the Veilguard, poiché di Bioware ho giocato solamente il primo Mass Effect e mi mancava questo grande pezzo di cultura del GDR nel mio bagaglio culturale.

Premesso che, come per la saga Si Fi, anche questa secondo me bisognerebbe valutarla tutta insieme, a differenza di quest'ultima, Dragon Age è più a compartimenti stagni, raccontando avventure tutto sommato separate l'una dall'altra, poiché se in Mass Effect è Shepard ad evolvere nel tempo insieme al mondo, qui è solamente il mondo che si adatta. Infatti come molti sapranno, queste trilogie variano a seconda delle tue scelte nei precedenti giochi, avendo (nei limiti delle capacità umane ovvio) una run differente ogni volta. Ora concentriamoci solo su Dragon Age Origins: con le mie 35 ore di gioco (che aumenteranno perché la voglia di fare altre run è tanta), posso dire tranquillamente che questo è uno dei migliori GDR della storia, grazie alla sua scrittura, al suo gameplay e al fatto che ogni azione porta ad una conseguenza intuibile (che significa semplicemente che le risposte che date non sono criptiche, capite quali sono le opzioni) e spesso drastica. E' un gioco invecchiato sia chiaro, e a differenza dei seguiti è anche estremamente anonimo dal punto di vista artistico, ma è tutto un canovaccio utilizzato per spalare litri di sangue su questa tela, raccontando una storia violenta, cupa che per me rappresenta al meglio il genere del Dark Fantasy nella maniera più classica del termine. Inoltre è secondo me un ottimo entry level del CRPG, essendo che non ha meccaniche di roleplay troppo approfondite e i parametri si legano esclusivamente ai Perk di combattimento, non ad abilità legate a statistiche per il dialogo o altro, pur essendo presenti. Ovviamente, in particolare la versione pc, ha qualche problema di ottimizzazione con cali di frame e crash, inoltre l'IA dei nemici spesso è... diciamo eccentrica e ti porta a elaborare strategie per farli inpazzire più che sconfiggerli e basta. Le campagne extra sono molto carine, alcune servono ad approfondire personaggi secondari, mentre altre (come quella di Morrigan e soprattutto l'espansione vera e propria The Awakening) sono estremamente importanti a tessere una narrativa talmente ben fatta da mettere in secondo piano un problema creativo che a me ha fatto particolarmente storcere il naso, ossia la semplicità artistica del mondo (inteso proprio come design delle strutture e mostri, la lore al contrario è eccellente).  Spendendo poi due parole proprio per The Awakening ossia l'espansione, ha un pregio che non pensavo avrei percepito essendo che dlc di questo tipo si concentrano più sulla trama... è divertentissimo! Usare un personaggio estremamente avanzato, e renderlo ancora più avanzato porta a creare build folli e uniche, partendo da una nuova base o da quella del gioco base. E poi non mi abituerò mai a vedere i personaggi che ho imparato ad amare o odiare essere presenti o assenti a seconda delle mie scelte, gioco a D&D cartaceo da anni e vederlo digitale fa un effetto incredibile.
Insomma se pensavate di buttarvi nel mondo dei Forgotten Realms con Baldur's Gate 3 ma avete sempre avuto paura che fosse troppo complesso... avete ragione, andate prima dal suo babbo e giocatevi Dragon Age Origins.

184914090.review:
Seré claro, si lo veis rebajado (a mi me lo regalaron como a 5 euros) comprarlo. Es un RPG clásico, con mecánicas simples, una historia muy buena, madura y que trata toques oscuros (cosa que pocos se atreven hoy en día). Gráficos antigüillos (2009), aunque con mods se pueden arreglar un poco. No requiere de un PC potente. Y en materia de dificultad, es relativamente fácil, aunque bastante estratégico y que exige atención por parte del jugador en las dificultades mas altas (si vais a jugar como mago, cuidado con el fuego amigo). Si tomáis la decisión, os esperan más de 50 horas de viaje aseguradas.
Lo único malo que puedo sacarle es que el juego está roto, necesita de un parche. Dejo aqui el vídeo que a mi me sirvió. https://youtu.be/px4Y3vNDNrQ?si=M2g4D2eBFiORXF5K Si no lo instaláis, puede que no os pase nada pero lo más seguro es que os vaya mal u os crashee todo el rato.

AVISO DE BUG IMPORTANTE: En la campaña de Awakening, en la misión el camino recto, justo después de que Velanna se una al grupo forzosamente, os metéis en unas ruinas/túneles donde el malo os dormirá y os quitará todo el equipamiento. Conservad un guardado anterior porque es muy posible que vuestro personaje pierda el equipamiento de forma permanente (me ha pasado tras 9 horas de DLC y he tenido que dejarlo). Podéis volver y guardar el equipamiento en el cofre del alcázar o algo por el estilo.

184910437.review:
While this is a game that requires some fixes to be applied by the player to get the game to remain stable and to cut down on crashes (crashes never ever fully go away), I think this game ran reasonably well considering the state of most Bioware PC games during the oughts. 
The game gets its subtitle "origins" from the different intros you get depending on your class and race. These intros are a couple hours long and have implications that lead all the way to the end of the game. This was very interesting as you are giving special treatment for being a noble or and elf here or a dwarf there.
The gameplay is purely mouse and keyboard driven but I was able to comfortably play the entire game on my steam deck (even though the game is marked as incompatible on steam deck). You are primarily reliant on the trackpads and your own ability to adjust the settings to suits your comforts. The default controls leave a bit to be desired and I was able to remap and set the keyboard controls so that I played the game like a 3rd person action game until I got into combat where I was able to quickly switch to a top down perspective with a mode switch. This sort of playability is dependent on how well you understand steam input and if you are not comfortable experimenting then this game may be too difficult to play on the steam deck.
However, on PC with a mouse abd keyboard,the game is extremely intuitive and plays just fine.
The world building in this game is top notch and it was a treat to learn the many details of the people, religions, and traditions in the world of Dragon Age. 
I liked how you had alot of free choice you never really feel like you are either making good or evil choices, like in alot of bioware games. You have no real alignment beyond a general reputation so you are free to treat one group or people badly for your own benefit and treat another kindly without some sort of alignment score being affected in a way you don't want. This decoupling of player statistics and abilities from morality like with Kotor, Jade empire and Mass effect makes dragon age stand out as a more pure Role playing experience, which leads me to think this is probably one of the best RPGs made by the company.

184822815.review:
Highly Recommended  
The best retro RPG that makes modern RPGs feel bland. The story is incredibly rich with no plot holes. Although we can't fully choose the storyline, we can decide how our character evolves over time. The story is so emotional that we can truly feel what our character is experiencing, allowing us to connect deeply. What's even more unique is that we can carry over our character from the main story into additional stories in the DLC, making the experience richer by letting us experience the beginning, journey, ending, and aftermath in the DLC. What I love about this franchise is that we can continue the story we create in this game, which then carries over into the next game, Dragon Age 2, where we get to experience the consequences or benefits of what we did in Dragon Age: Origins.
Overall, the best retro RPG!

[h2][/h2]
[*][b]Story[/b]: 8.5/10

[/list]

DAO is a tough choice in 2024. You can't mind the dated graphic, but it also crashes a lot, you need to do some modding to make it a bit smoother. 
Now, it has some of the best dialogue I've seen in a video game. Even the random banter the party engages in is enjoyable and full of lore, world context, or amusing interpersonal interaction. Combat is clunky, and it's better to play it more as a strategy game than a combat one, but the rest of the game is so worth it that one can overlook this dated aspect of it. 
It is worth playing, yes!!! Not for a completionist but for the character development and lore, it's a masterpiece.

184579108.review:
Easily one of my favorite games. It has a rich story, well-built characters, fun gameplay, and everything I love about RPGs. 
The dialogues are exceptionally well-written—so much so that, during my playthroughs, I usually ignore background interactions between companions. But in DAO, the lines were so funny that I often found myself stopping just to listen. That's when I knew it was THAT good.

You can tell the game was made in 2009, but I couldn't care less. I enjoyed it so much that I couldn’t be bothered.

There is a known issue with a memory leak. For those familiar with these problems, you know that unless a fix is made by the dev team, the issue sticks around. That’s the case with DAO. There’s no official solution, but there is a W/A using a mod. I strongly suggest using it—it helps extend the time between crashes. Oh, and don’t make my mistake, quick save as often as possible XD
I promise—it’s worth it.

184565833.review:
Daha oyunu ilk açışımda müzikteki ciddiyetten, ara sahneden anlamıştım ne kadar kaliteli bir oyun oynayacağımı ve her bir saniyesinden zevk alarak oynayıp, bitirdim. Prime Bioware, önce ki oyunlarında yaptığı işi daha ileriye taşıyarak hem oynanışı hem de hikaye anlatımını daha da geliştirmiş. Ara sahneler olsun, karakterlerin birbirleri arasında ki diyalogları olsun her şey çok çok iyi. Yazım kalitesi Prime Bioware'in eski oyunlarında olduğu gibi en üst seviyede, korkusuzca yazılmış diyaloglar ve seçimler sayesinde hem gülüp eğlendim hem de kendimi gerçekten oluşturduğum karakterin yerine koyabildim, Grey Warden gibi hissedebildim. Ayrıca oyun boyunca yoldaşlarımızın kendi aralarında atışmaları çok keyifliydi, favori ikilim Morrigan ve Alistair oldu atışmalar arasında. Morrigan'a ayrı bir parantez açmak istiyorum, bence Bioware'in oluşturduğu en iyi karakterlerden bir tanesi. Gerçekten farklı bir kafa da olan, sıradanlıktan uzak yan karakterlere bayılıyorum ve Morrigan da tam öyle bir karakter.

2024 yılında 2009'da çıkmış bir oyunu oynarken sanki yeni çıkmış bir oyunu oynuyormuşum gibi hissettim ve ne zaman eski ama döneminin kaliteli, yüksek puanlar almış oyunlarını oynasam böyle hissediyorum. Bunun en büyük sebebi de güya yeni nesil dediğimiz oyunlar yalnızca grafiklere abanarak atmosfer yaratmayı, hikaye ve diyalog yazımını, oyuna ruh katmayı unuttuğu için. Örnek vermek gerekirse, Dragon age'in son oyununu görünce bu oyuna ne kadar büyük bir ihanet yapıldığını anlıyorsunuz. Resmen hali hazırda mükemmel olan bir seriyi iğrenç ve ruhsuz bir oyunla serinin ismini lekelediler. Bu yüzden sürekli Prime Bioware diyorum çünkü eski Bioware'den en ufak bir eser kalmadı artık.

Kısacası Dragon age Origins gerçekten bir başyapıt. Öyle ki Baldurs gate 3 gibi kusursuz bir RPG oyununa doğrudan esin kaynağı olabilecek kadar. Oynanış, diyalog tarzı, hikaye benzerliklerine kadar çok benziyor Dragon Age Origins ve Baldurs Gate 3. Yukarıda dediğim gibi yalnızca grafiğe değil diğer unsurları da unutmayarak her şeyi çok iyi yaparak son yılların en iyi RPG oyunu olan Baldurs Gate 3'ü sevmişseniz onun esin kaynağı olan bu oyuna da mutlaka bakmalısınız, pişman olmazsınız.

Ayrıca oyun eski olduğu için çökme sorunları yaşanabiliyor. Bunun için yapılmış bir yama var, o yamayı yüklerseniz sorun çözülecektir.

Oh, and the DLCs are so vast, let me tell you that beating the main campaigns endboss is actually just the end of the tutorial.

I hope you will love this game as much as I did, lethallin and lethallan.

184436062.review:
[h1]Role-Playing Freedom[/h1]

This game is the beginning of the renowned Dragon Age series, which is beloved for a reason. It is a dark western fantasy RPG with a wealth of dialogue options that satisfy the need for diverse role-playing experiences. There is also a [b][u]great degree of freedom of choice, respecting player decisions and allowing players to significantly impact the outcomes of major events in the story.[/u][/b] In many cases, players are put into moral dilemmas and the players just cannot achieve a perfect solution no matter what. Players are forced to cope with the less adverse outcome. There are also [b][u]multiple backgrounds available to start a character. Each of them would experience a very different prologue.[/u][/b] And they have slightly different interactions in the later parts of the game. In terms of role-playing diversity, this game is a classic Bioware masterpiece.

[h1]Behind the Times[/h1]

Unfortunately, this game has a lot of flaws due to it being more than a decade old.

[h3]Poor support and maintenance[/h3] 

In order to play this game on a modern PC, players are required to [b][u]install community-made unofficial patches.[/u][/b] This is quite jarring, considering BioWare is such a big company and seems too lazy to provide basic support for one of their most adored titles. Here's a list of mods and patches that I found to be helpful for most new players.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Mod/Patch Name[/th]
        [th]Function[/th]
        [th]Importance[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]4 GB patch/LAA patch (choose any)[/td]
        [td]Allocate more than 2 GB of RAM to the game[/td]
        [td] The game would crash without it.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Quinn fixpack[/td]
        [td]Fixes bugs[/td]
        [td]Not essential to launch the game, still highly recommended.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]FTG UI mod[/td]
        [td]Change the font size[/td]
        [td]Words could be seen more clearly under modern resolution.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Any texture pack/Graphics mods you see fit[/td]
        [td]Modernize the graphics[/td]
        [td]Not necessary for me, might be a must for some. [/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3397808959
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3397805447

[h3]Tedious Enemy Encounters[/h3]

It is a common practice that developers put swarms of pawns obstructing the path of the players in many games. As making unique encounters eats up a ton of resources, developers have no choice but to create tedious filler fights reluctantly. I understand their difficulties, considering the limited resources available per project. However, Dragon Age Origin [b][u]includes swarms after swarms of filler encounters to an insane level.[/u][/b] It is torture getting through hordes of Darkspwans even on autopilot. The level of repetitiveness is unacceptable, even considering it is a game released back in 2008.

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]

Overall, I have mixed feelings about this game. However, given the cringy options and dialogue in the most recent adaptation of the Dragon Age series, I would recommend the original legacy version for gamers seeking to cleanse their souls.

184262522.review:
Oh Origins... a game that divides a fandom to this date and whose nostalgia glasses are thicker than tank’s armour. A tricky game to review, as there’s Origins the 2009 game, the well-executed, magnificent world that has made an entire group of people misunderstand what dark fantasy is; and Origins the 2024 game, a frustrating RPG, with a bad gameplay experience and story elements that have not aged well. Both these games coexist, but when this game gets recommended, often it is the 09 version, and often, you shall experience the 2024 version as a new player. 
Do I recommend this game? Only if you’re already a DA fan. Unfortunately, the gameplay isn’t clunky like ME1, it is simply poor. The story had to be brilliant to overcome this, that it isn’t. While good, DAO leans too hard into edginess to make its grim world, rather than treating it with the tact it deserves.  6/10.
Gameplay:
I despise when people reviewing something claim it’s objectively bad, but for Origins I shall make this exception: It’s objectively bad.
For a CRPG, there’s very little unique tactics one will use. Contrasting this to DOS2, where constantly using the environment to your advantage, and whose many abilities have a counter is where you’ll find the biggest shortcomings. Most of the more powerful abilities lack or have a highly specific counter: hexes lack a remove curse; AoE attacks such as fireball give knock down, burning and hit a huge area, making escape near impossible if the attacked was launched; abilities that strike multiple characters such as scattershot and chain lightning have a very lenient line of sight to hit your party to name a few. It’s like playing chess with all pawns as queens, whoever is playing white, launches the attack and wins. This isn’t saying that OP abilities don’t exist in other games, but that the gameplay doesn’t revolve around them.
Mission design is bad. Not a matter for debate, this game 6th most endorsed mod is skip the fade, a mod that deletes an entire section of a quest in this game.
Most games with dedicated quests will have their quests clock in 1-2 hours at most and break down them in multiple entries if longer than that. DAO will have plenty clocking at 3 hours, meaning you’ll often stop in the middle of a quest.  The story, aka the interesting part, is focused at the start and end, with a boring middle where you’re stuck with the gameplay. This is not to say that all quests are bad, Ostigar or the Landsmeet are great, but that many quests, especially in act 2, are held back by their structure rather than their narrative.
In the end, Origins is a game where you put up with the playing it. 
Visuals:
Once more, objectively poor. The graphics belong in 2005, not in 2009 when this game was released. This is, however, the easiest part to look away from, but the visual identity is not. 
This is whiplash, I’m reviewing while revisiting the entire series, but Veilguard’s art direction exposes how uncreative origins is. A simple thing such as the pallet of the corrupted city being toned out from the rest of the game goes a long way. The big moment of horror from this game, the Broodmother, is just Jabba the hut but woman, desire demons are simply a naked woman... You can do a lot more with the limited graphical resources. Look at DA2 Kirkwall’s few different regions have a unique feel, while one would be hard pressed to distinguish between the alienage, a ghetto, from the market of Denerim. 
Narrative: 
So why would you play this game? After all I have been only bashing it for a while. One word, the world.
Thedas makes the galaxy in ME feel tame, and I don’t say this lightly. This feels like a world in which people live, magic is a political issue which nations diverge on, the chant is one of the few true religions in fantasy etc. The game borrows elements of the real world and twists them, e.g Andraste is Jesus, but a woman who was burned at the stake, thus the clergy is entirely built by women and the dead are cremated. These little things make the world feel alive. While plenty will be exposed through conversation, some will be done exclusively through codex entries, the entire elven pantheon for example relies on those. 
Plot wise, it is sufficient. It will not set the world on fire, but you’re a member of the only order who can stop the threat, thus you go gathering allies to face such a threat. Simple, but effective. 
The characters are rough diamonds, interesting with few exceptions, but arguably sticking too close to the DnD alignment chart assigned. Morrigan is the best example, as both the best character in this game, with this ruthless survival first mentality, yet she’ll trust the magister slaver in the alienage will keep his end of the bargain as she must be the “neutral evil” character, rather than pragmatic.  
The PC, the warden, is the only silent protagonist of the series, which means great freedom in choice but surprisingly less reactivity than I remembered. The evil path is funny, but it is no dark urge with its own dramatic arc. As for the smaller elements, such as your race, DAO loud moments, such as the prologue or meeting again your faction, but at times simply they don’t make a difference, being a dalish elf in the allienage. The best example comes at the end of the Landsmeet, where you cannot become Alistair’s or Annora’s consort if you’re an elf, after all you’re a seen as a lesser people by many, yet you’ll choose the ruler of Ferelden. The game at the same time is following and ignoring its own lore, and something that surely would be criticized had it happened in other entries. 
The biggest shortcoming of Origins is its edginess, very much akin of a teen who wishes to show there are now an adult. For instance, Sten will just admit to murdering an entire family of farmers and mechanically the game is asking you to recruit him. Subtle was not a word in the writing room, and the course correction will be swift for the next games.
It is bizarre how much this game leans into extreme violence and sexual assault; in the Dalish quest, instead of having the children of a character being killed leading to a curse, the boy must be tortured to death, while the girl must be r*ped and take her own life when she finds out to be pregnant. Just killing the children would suffice to set up the cycle of vengeance that the quest wishes to explore, the extra adds nothing. Personally, it makes the story worse, beyond feeling forced, it doesn’t treat said violence with the tact to explore it in a serious manner. It’s a cheap attempt at shock value and the vague concept of “darkness”.
Finally, the pedantic, and quite useless, discussion of if this game is dark fantasy. While it certainly borrows elements of such, it has always been a high fantasy narrative. Having elements such as slavery, racism or extreme violence doesn’t make a narrative dark fantasy, horror does. The main horror element is the blight and its corruption, which is not the centre of the narrative, present mostly in the start and act 3. One barely gets to see the effect of the blight in the world. We don’t get, for example, to choose which city to help from its wrath. Denerim at the end, doesn’t seem unique, and looks like a town sacked by any army, not corrupted by the blight. The game is about uniting the forces to fight it, and quelling the infighting, and how far are you willing to go, it is closer to ME3, a classic hero’s journey. 
So no, I don’t believe DAO is dark fantasy. Imo it was a marketing stick that because of the severe course correction this franchise has made, became truth to distinguish it from the other three games. 
In summary, DAO’s narrative is good if you can look past the edgier elements, that have aged poorly, but is one overrated.

184015516.review:
Definitely among the top of my list of favorite games! 


WORLD DESIGN:
DA:O is from a time when RPG's aren't also trying so hard to be bloated open-world games. It's level design offers just enough to give you a sense of adventure without huge empty areas to artificially pad playtime like in most recent RPG's. This allows for a more balanced pacing between experiencing the game's story and exploration. The world itself is oozing with atmosphere. From Ostagar to The circle of Magi and from Denerim to the Deep Roads, every place in this game is designed to be unique, beautiful, and interesting. (I admit that the Fade and the deeproads sections, as gorgeous as they are, can be tiresome after the first play-though...so there's that.)

STORY
The over-arching story is simple and not that open ended. BUT! There are so many fun role-playing decisions from as early as the character creation menu up until the end of the story. This ensures that each play-through is different and nuanced offering tons of replay value. You may always be the hero of Ferelden by the end. Question is, what kind of hero will you be? Will you be a saint, a kind hero who tries help to everyone? Or will you be a an malicious person who hurts others but happens to defeat a great threat and therefore save the day, a hero in name only? Your actions throughout the game will decide. 

COMPANIONS:
Probably one of the most memorable and my fav group of companions in all of DA (even Bioware) games. Maybe even my fav companions in all of gaming. They're fun to engage with and have depth. They feel like real people thanks to the phenomenal voice work and competent writing. The banter system is peak too. Also, there is a believable reason why my PC is suddenly the leader of the group established early on.

COMBAT:
Combat may be janky, outdated even, but the party tactics, an improvement from Baldur's gate before it imho, is engaging to play with. The implementaion of this mechanic is among the things that really sets DAO apart from the other DA games for me. In DA2 I never needed it and it was so janky and barely even there in DAI that I just gave up on using it.

Played this for the first time more than 10 years after its release and it is still an excellent cRPG. It is also the only rendition of RTwP that I found enjoyable in the genre as it draws for the strengths of both Real Time and Turn Based (snappy actions, animation cancelling... while retaining a strategic layer that's not overwhelming). Great companions and interactions, interesting story and universe although clearly inspired of the classics of the genre. 
It was quite interesting playing this game after Baldur's Gate 3 and seeing just how much it inspired it on its storytelling and small details like camp interactions.
The only part of the game that I felt was a bit too long for my liking was the Deep Roads during the Dwarf part of the main quest. Even today if you don't mind the visuals it is a very solid and accessible cRPG.

It's hard to recommend this game for PC after the issues I've had with it. It may be better on console, but this version is full of problems. As a game, independent of all software issues, I had a decent time playing it. However, the software itself is so janky that I cannot finish the game.

I couldn't even start the game for the longest time. I had to look up fixes online, and it took me a couple hours to successfully open the software and start a playthrough. Then, when I was finally able to get into the game itself, it started crashing constantly. I have an incredibly powerful PC. It can play most modern games with High to Ultra graphics settings. This game, however, would only stop crashing after I turned all graphics settings to Medium or Low. Even then, I still had the occasional crash. I started saving all the time just so I wouldn't lose all my progress when the game fritzed out.

The other software issue that I noticed was a terrible memory leak problem.

Overall, I just couldn't continue playing. The storyline was fun, and I eventually got used to the combat system, even though it's not my favorite. I also appreciate the incredible RPG mechanics that allow your decisions to be truly meaningful in many situations. The pacing slowed down in the later Acts, after a really well-paced first Act, but I would have continued if it weren't for the pervasive software problems. I just can't recommend this game to PC players in good conscience with all the issues it has.

183789717.review:
Well, I don't have much to say other than praise for such a masterpiece in the form of a digital game. At the very peak of my arrogance, I turned my back when people talked about this game. Such was my ignorance that I almost ended up committing an irreversible act: ignoring this jewel. Now that I've made it clear how much I enjoyed the game, let's dive into a detailed analysis (at least as far as the steam characters limit allow me to go!).

Gameplay: Dragon Age: Origins features a mix of real-time combat and turn-based elements via the pause system, which could have been a major strength but isn't fully realized. On difficulties above normal (hard or nightmare), it's nearly impossible to overcome challenges without exploiting the pause feature to manage your party and resources meticulously. Players must closely monitor each party member's actions, health, and enemies, making battles highly demanding in terms of micromanagement.
The game's tactics system for party members, designed to automate certain behaviors in specific situations, is flawed. Many tactical options don't work as intended or are impractical for more challenging encounters. For instance, commands like "use potion when health is below X%" can be ineffective due to resource scarcity, especially in higher difficulties. Additionally, commands for combat actions often have unexplained cooldowns, causing party members to act unpredictably.
Class gameplay varies significantly. Playing as a warrior with a two-handed sword, for example, requires careful planning early on but isn't inherently difficult once you understand the mechanics. However, certain encounters, especially against mages, can be frustrating due to the imbalance in combat dynamics. The dual weapon system, while theoretically adding depth, is impractical due to limited level cap and stat distribution, making it essential to specialize in one weapon type.
Balancing issues are pervasive. While the early game can be punishingly difficult, requiring precise knowledge of the game's mechanics and meta strategies, later stages can make the player feel overwhelmingly powerful. This inconsistency detracts from the overall experience, making some parts of the game feel artificially difficult while others are too easy.

Story - I can't praise this enough. The story of Dragon Age: Origins is simply one of the best when it comes to western RPGs. The quality is so high that you occasionally wonder if this is really a game or not. Characters are ridiculously well written, from the most random NPC to the most important story characters; even with the technical limitations of the time, many scenarios manage to convey a LOT of the history of this vast continent; much of the codex material, the texts that tell a bit about the world's lore, quests, characters, and so on during the game, are of extremely high quality, something I rarely find in games like this one. In summary, you genuinely feel like you're living in that world and your choices truly matter. Everything you do, no matter how simple it may seems to be, ends up altering the overall course of events in some way. I really didn't expect such freedom in such an old game! That said, I'd like to make it clear that even though all the game's text is of the highest quality, there are still some... problems. The most relevant here would be the number of dialogue lines party members have at their respective affection levels. I personally exhausted most of Alistair's dialogues early in the game. This meant that the only texts I had with him later were his reactions to some main story events. It's worth noting, however, that the individual number of dialogue lines for each party member is by no means objectively small. The problem lies in the distribution of these dialogues not being done that well, leaving the player with little to see from the character after 10-15 hours of gameplay. The characters also interact with each other during your adventures, and it's ridiculously fun to see they acting so naturally. Watching Morrigan pick on Alistair or Sten getting the upper hand in every argument with her is so simple yet magical.

Sound - The game's voice acting is phenomenal. Almost every character in it has a voice, except our protagonist, who produces grunts (and says a few words during fights). You can feel the emotion behind every single line coming from every single character. The nuances of their personalities, their specificities, etc., is also 'transmuted' through their voices. It's truly one of the best voice-acting performances I've ever seen in a game! The soundtrack, on the other hand, is VERY good at some moments but ends up being 'okay' at others. Don't get me wrong, every piece of music in dragon age origins is amazing and worthy of applause; the problem is that enclosed segments in long dungeons make certain tracks in particular become saturated. Overall, I have no complaints other than that, so I'd say the score is 9/10. It's not as good as the soundtrack of games like Elden Ring or The Witcher 3, but it doesn't fall behind any other game out there. Below a 10, but above all the 8s haha.

Performance - This is a point I rarely touch on, but here it is necessary. If you intend to play dragon age origins now in 2024, it's important to be aware of the need for mods. The game itself has several bugs withing the PC version that can completely break your run. Your save is at such a high risk of getting soft-locked at so many different points in the main game without those mods that it's impossible to recommend playing without them. Another important point to highlight is the crashing. While most of the base game's significant bugs and its expansions are easily fixed with those incredible mods available, the same can't be said for the crashing. In my experience, I can count on one hand the number of times I could play for more than an hour without a single crash. At certain moments, the game would crash every 10-15 minutes, which can be incredibly frustrating. It got so bad that I developed the incredible habit of saving ALL THE TIME, knowing that at any moment I could lose my progress. You might be thinking it was a compatibility issue with the mods I installed, but I'm afraid that's not the case. Each of the most popular mods that fix the bugs is compatible with each other, so there's no compatibility issue with them. If you have doubts about which to install, there's a guide on Steam with a list of mods that fix the game's and its expansions' significant bugs and soft locks and are compatible with each other.

Conclusion - If you played Skyrim and liked the empty text present in it, which was a step back even from its predecessor Oblivion, I strongly recommend sitting down and enjoying the dragon age origins experience. The text is deep, the world is alive, the characters DO exist, and your choices matter. You won't read the codex within the game forcibly, but out of curiosity to learn more about this magical world. The soundtrack also holds up well and the voice acting is impeccable. I couldn't recommend this game more than i'm doing haha. It's worth noting that this only applies to dragon age origins; I'm not praising the expanded world in dragon age 2 and Inquisition. Both games are extremely weak compared to Origins in this regard and don't deserve nearly as much praise. Dragon Age 2 is still a well-above-average experience if you can endure the gameplay, but Inquisition, apart from the romances, which are probably the best in the franchise, is at best 'okay'. If you want a complete game, play Origins and be happy.

Addendum - This analysis refers purely to the base game and the Witch Hunt expansion. Dragon Age: Origins Awakening, the expansion continuing Origins' story, is good but doesn't reach the level of the main game. Addressing it in this analysis would significantly reduce the overall game's level, so I've come to chose to leave my opinion on it out.

I do NOT suggest you buy this game, no matter how cheap it is, because:
1) Resolution problems.  The game is NOT make for anything more than old VGA resolutions; and the UI does NOT scale (without mod's).  Then with the mods it seems to be hit and miss.
*Update -  FtG ui mod and Nathanaels 4k both fix the UI problem, however they both break if you install FtG's hotbar fix (see below)
2) System crashes - multiple backups.  I have 4 total backups, 1 auto and 3 named.  Up until this last one, the auto backup (backup 4) would load, no matter what.  Now, no - crash.  Backup Main 1, Main 2, Main really, and auto (whatever), all crash.  
*Update on crashes:  I was able to get that part fixed (no crashes now) by making the following settings:  resolution 3840x2160 / detail low / AA off / Texture low /  vertical sync off / frame-buffer off / disable multiple render on / aspect ratio disable on.
The basics are, the new cards are not fully compliant with the old games so stripping the settings to 'potato' will overcome the crash.
3) (original 3 removed, new added) - Discovered that the hotbar (all your spells, or abilities, randomly vanishes) so you install the "hotbar fix" which breaks the UI fix.  So.... Install the hotbar fix, lock the hotbar, then uninstall the hotbar fix, so the UI fix returns.
The game seems to be fun, if only it was playable - dropping the resolution "down that far" really messes up my desktop on both monitors.  Since the game is, for all purposes, no longer supported - just by pass it until someone resurrects it in a playable form...  
JMHO

183644587.review: I first played DAO back when it released, on the PS3. It was like no other fantasy game I'd played, with a rich origins story and companion interaction- as well as romances- that were developed and unique. I'd never cared about the people in a game so much as I did with Origins. Of course, I replayed it several times, then got it for PC, modded it heavily, and so on. While playing BG3, I was reminded of Origins in terms of its writing, and after the rather disappointing Veilguard game, decided to get a Steam copy and see how Origins was today. It's still utterly wonderful, with writing, companions, and player freedom that are outstanding even today. Your choices really do matter. In terms of technical stuff, you will almost certainly need to mod it, but fortunately there are many well-proven and well-known ways around it. You'll want to get the modded .exe file and 4GB patch, and there are some good QOL fixes on a well-populated Nexus page. You will probably also need to "trick" the game into thinking you have a 32-bit PC. The game runs well enough *outside* of Denerim and Orzammar- the infamous memory leak issues mean you might need to lower your graphics to medium or even low in these places to avoid CTD issues. It's less easy to mod and stable than, say Morrowind, but it's another great older game that you can still enjoy today, especially if you enjoy quality writing, lore, and anything approaching Divinity or BG3.

183612303.review: Do you all remember when Bioware used to be a legendary game development company that puts out banger games after banger games like the Mass Effect and KOTOR games??? Yeah, me too. ANYWAY! Dragon Age: Origins. Thank you to my dear friend, BobbyBurst, for gifting me Dragon Age: Veilguard because it has given me a good excuse to play the Dragon Age games again. Origins is one of my most favorite RPGs that I played a ton of on my Xbox (and my PS3 but I actually never finished the game on that system). For a game that came out in 2009, it still holds up well. The game still looks good, the story's amazing, the characters well-written and loved (not you, Loghain), and so much lore from the Codices! All of your companions that you meet along the way is one of the things that makes Origins amazing. The banters between them are just great especially the ones involving Alistair. I love that man. Such a goober. This is also the version of the game that I got to experience all the DLCs as on the Xbox, I could only play Awakening. They are good! If you want to experience what Origins has to fully offer along with the choices you make affecting the rest of the games, I recommend you play the DLCs. Except the Darkspawn one. That one is just a "What If" DLC so it doesn't really add much to the main story, and I skipped it. The order of the DLCs you want to play is Awakening, Golem of Amgarrak, and Witch Hunt. Awakening will be the longest DLC as it adds a bunch of new stuff like companions. Golem and Witch Hunt are pretty short as I was able to get through Golem within an hour and a half and Witch Hunt roughly around the same time. Bioware stated they would never make DLCs as long as Awakening again, and they indeed kept their word. Oh yeah, I just remembered, there is a DLC for Leliana. It's okay. I mean if you want more backstory on Leliana, I recommend you play but if you don't care, another safe to skip DLC. There is also the Soldier's Peak and Return to Ostagar DLCs. Both are also okay too and are great to do if you want the extra XPs and Gears plus some more lore and resolution of giving a certain character a proper funeral. Despite all the praise I give the game, Origins does have its issues. One of the main ones is that if you want have a good experience with the game not plagued by crashes, you need to mod this game along with doing some steps to get the DLCs to appear despite this being the Ultimate Edition. I recommend going to the "Guides" section of Origins and find two people, G the Glamorous and Dreams. The two guides made by these wonderful folks is what you need to get the game fully working and going. I noticed when I play Origins, the game will eventually start to stutter and drop in frames. Granted, it is probably because I play as a mage and decide to throw all my AoE spells as soon as any battle starts but anyway, the best way to fix it is to save your game and restart Origins should this issue occur and it will occur throughout your playthrough. The combat in this game is okay. It is not bad by any means but it does get repetitive by the end as once you find your favorite ability combo, you will stick with that for the rest of the game. Origins is also one of those games where I honestly just recommend playing on Easy or install a mod that stops friendly fire from happening on Normal because I do not know why friendly fire is a thing on Normal. Dragon Age 2 does it where it only happens on the hardest difficulty. In Origins, it is either Easy or install a mod for Normal as it really makes combat more annoying than it needs to be when Wynne or Morrigan or even you the player uses a spell or another ability that hurts, knocks down, freezes, etc everyone. Another reason to just stick to Easy as this game has moment where the difficulty spikes for really no reason which can take you out of the experience. Actually, the difficulty may suddenly spike even on easy. The game is weird in that aspect. Overall, Dragon Age: Origins is still a very amazing game that I recommend to anyone that enjoys RPGs and want to get into the series so they can prepare for Veilguard. I know I am!!! I am excited and dreading to play Veilguard! 9/10!!! The mod where you can bring your Mabari Doggy Pet with you even with a full party is VERY NECESSARY!!!
